31 Issue Date: 24/01/2003
32
33 This file contains the compilation options for AES (Rijndael) and code
34 that is common across encryption, key scheduling and table generation.
35
36 OPERATION
37
38 These source code files implement the AES algorithm Rijndael designed by
39 Joan Daemen and Vincent Rijmen. The version in aes.c is designed for
40 block and key sizes of 128, 192 and 256 bits (16, 24 and 32 bytes) while
41 that in aespp.c provides for block and keys sizes of 128, 160, 192, 224
42 and 256 bits (16, 20, 24, 28 and 32 bytes). This file is a common header
43 file for these two implementations and for aesref.c, which is a reference
44 implementation.
45
46 This version is designed for flexibility and speed using operations on
47 32-bit words rather than operations on bytes. It provides aes_both fixed
48 and dynamic block and key lengths and can also run with either big or
49 little endian internal byte order (see aes.h). It inputs block and key
50 lengths in bytes with the legal values being 16, 24 and 32 for aes.c and
51 16, 20, 24, 28 and 32 for aespp.c
52
53 THE CIPHER INTERFACE
54
55 aes_08t (an unsigned 8-bit type)
56 aes_32t (an unsigned 32-bit type)
57 aes_fret (a signed 16 bit type for function return values)
58 aes_good (value != 0, a good return)
59 aes_bad (value == 0, an error return)
60 struct aes_ctx (structure for the cipher encryption context)
61 struct aes_ctx (structure for the cipher decryption context)
62 aes_rval the function return type (aes_fret if not DLL)
63
64 C subroutine calls:
65
66 aes_rval aes_set_block_size(unsigned int blen, aes_ctx cx[1]);
67 aes_rval aes_set_encrypt_key(const unsigned char in_key[],
68 unsigned int klen, aes_ctx cx[1]);
69 aes_rval aes_encrypt_block(const unsigned char in_blk[],
70 unsigned char out_blk[], const aes_ctx cx[1]);
71
72 aes_rval aes_dec_len(unsigned int blen, aes_ctx cx[1]);
73 aes_rval aes_set_decrypt_key(const unsigned char in_key[],
74 unsigned int klen, aes_ctx cx[1]);
75 aes_rval aes_decrypt_block(const unsigned char in_blk[],
76 unsigned char out_blk[], const aes_ctx cx[1]);
77
78 IMPORTANT NOTE: If you are using this C interface and your compiler does
79 not set the memory used for objects to zero before use, you will need to
80 ensure that cx.n_blk is set to zero before using these subroutine calls.
81
82 C++ aes class subroutines:
83
84 class AESclass for encryption
85 class AESclass for decryption
86
87 aes_rval len(unsigned int blen = 16);
88 aes_rval key(const unsigned char in_key[], unsigned int klen);
89 aes_rval blk(const unsigned char in_blk[], unsigned char out_blk[]);
90
91 aes_rval len(unsigned int blen = 16);
92 aes_rval key(const unsigned char in_key[], unsigned int klen);
93 aes_rval blk(const unsigned char in_blk[], unsigned char out_blk[]);
94
95 The block length inputs to set_block and set_key are in numbers of
96 BYTES, not bits. The calls to subroutines must be made in the above
97 order but multiple calls can be made without repeating earlier calls
98 if their parameters have not changed. If the cipher block length is
99 variable but set_blk has not been called before cipher operations a
100 value of 16 is assumed (that is, the AES block size). In contrast to
101 earlier versions the block and key length parameters are now checked
102 for correctness and the encryption and decryption routines check to
103 ensure that an appropriate key has been set before they are called.
104
105 COMPILATION
106
107 The files used to provide AES (Rijndael) are
108
109 a. aes.h for the definitions needed for use in C.
110 b. aescpp.h for the definitions needed for use in C++.
111 c. aesopt.h for setting compilation options (also includes common
112 code).
113 d. aescrypt.c for encryption and decrytpion, or
114 e. aescrypt.asm for encryption and decryption using assembler code.
115 f. aeskey.c for key scheduling.
116 g. aestab.c for table loading or generation.
117
118 The assembler code uses the NASM assembler. The above files provice
119 block and key lengths of 16, 24 and 32 bytes (128, 192 and 256 bits).
120 If aescrypp.c and aeskeypp.c are used instead of aescrypt.c and
121 aeskey.c respectively, the block and key lengths can then be 16, 20,
122 24, 28 or 32 bytes. However this code has not been optimised to the
123 same extent and is hence slower (esepcially for the AES block size
124 of 16 bytes).
125
126 To compile AES (Rijndael) for use in C code use aes.h and exclude
127 the AES_DLL define in aes.h
128
129 To compile AES (Rijndael) for use in in C++ code use aescpp.h and
130 exclude the AES_DLL define in aes.h
131
132 To compile AES (Rijndael) in C as a Dynamic Link Library DLL) use
133 aes.h, include the AES_DLL define and compile the DLL. If using
134 the test files to test the DLL, exclude aes.c from the test build
135 project and compile it with the same defines as used for the DLL
136 (ensure that the DLL path is correct)
137
138 CONFIGURATION OPTIONS (here and in aes.h)
139
140 a. define BLOCK_SIZE in aes.h to set the cipher block size (16, 24
141 or 32 for the standard code, or 16, 20, 24, 28 or 32 for the
142 extended code) or leave this undefined for dynamically variable
143 block size (this will result in much slower code).
144 b. set AES_DLL in aes.h if AES (Rijndael) is to be compiled as a DLL
145 c. You may need to set PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER to define the byte order.
146 d. If you want the code to run in a specific internal byte order, then
147 INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER must be set accordingly.
148 e. set other configuration options decribed below.
149*/
150
151#ifndef _AESOPT_H
152#define _AESOPT_H
153
154#if defined(__cplusplus)
155extern "C"
156{
157#endif
158
159/* START OF CONFIGURATION OPTIONS
160
161 USE OF DEFINES
162
163 Later in this section there are a number of defines that control the
164 operation of the code. In each section, the purpose of each define is
165 explained so that the relevant form can be included or excluded by
166 setting either 1's or 0's respectively on the branches of the related
167 #if clauses.
168*/
169
170/* DO NOT CHANGE THE FOLLOWING EIGHT DEFINES */
171
172#define NO_TABLES 0
173#define ONE_TABLE 1
174#define FOUR_TABLES 4
175#define NONE 0
176#define PARTIAL 1
177#define FULL 2
178#define AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1234 /* byte 0 is least significant (i386) */
179#define AES_BIG_ENDIAN 4321 /* byte 0 is most significant (mc68k) */
180
181/* 1. PLATFORM SPECIFIC INCLUDES */
182
183#if defined( __CRYPTLIB__ ) && !defined( INC_ALL ) && !defined( INC_CHILD )
184#include "crypt/aes.h"
185#else
186 #include "aes.h"
187#endif
188
189#if defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNU_LIBRARY__)
190//# include <endian.h>
191//# include <byteswap.h>
192#elif defined(__CRYPTLIB__)
193# if defined( INC_ALL )
194# include "crypt.h"
195# elif defined( INC_CHILD )
196# include "../crypt.h"
197# else
198# include "crypt.h"
199# endif
200# if defined(DATA_LITTLEENDIAN)
201# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
202# else
203# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
204# endif
205#elif defined(_MSC_VER)
206# include <stdlib.h>
207#elif !defined(WIN32)
208# include <stdlib.h>
209# if !defined (_ENDIAN_H)
210# include <sys/param.h>
211# else
212# include _ENDIAN_H
213# endif
214#endif

216/* 2. BYTE ORDER IN 32-BIT WORDS
217
218 To obtain the highest speed on processors with 32-bit words, this code
219 needs to determine the order in which bytes are packed into such words.
220 The following block of code is an attempt to capture the most obvious
221 ways in which various environemnts define byte order. It may well fail,
222 in which case the definitions will need to be set by editing at the
223 points marked **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** below.
224*/
225#if !defined(PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER)
226#if defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) || defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
227# if defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
228# if defined(BYTE_ORDER)
229# if (BYTE_ORDER == LITTLE_ENDIAN)
230# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
231# elif (BYTE_ORDER == BIG_ENDIAN)
232# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
233# endif
234# endif
235# elif defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && !defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
236# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
237# elif !defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
238# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
239# endif
240#elif defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) || defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
241# if defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
242# if defined(_BYTE_ORDER)
243# if (_BYTE_ORDER == _LITTLE_ENDIAN)
244# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
245# elif (_BYTE_ORDER == _BIG_ENDIAN)
246# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
247# endif
248# endif
249# elif defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && !defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
250# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
251# elif !defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
252# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
253# endif
254#elif 0 /* **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** */
255#define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
256#elif 0 /* **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** */
257#define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
258#elif (('1234' >> 24) == '1')
259# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
260#elif (('4321' >> 24) == '1')
261# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
262#endif
263#endif
264
265#if !defined(PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER)
266# error Please set undetermined byte order (lines 241 or 243 of aesopt.h).
267#endif
268
269/* 3. FUNCTIONS REQUIRED
270
271 This implementation provides five main subroutines which provide for
272 setting block length, setting encryption and decryption keys and for
273 encryption and decryption. When the assembler code is not being used
274 the following definition blocks allow the selection of the routines
275 that are to be included in the compilation.
276*/
277#if 1
278#define ENCRYPTION
279#define ENCRYPTION_KEY_SCHEDULE
280#endif
281
282#if 0
283#define DECRYPTION
284#define DECRYPTION_KEY_SCHEDULE
285#endif
286
287/* 4. ASSEMBLER SUPPORT
288
289 This define (which can be on the command line) enables the use of the
290 assembler code routines for encryption and decryption with the C code
291 only providing key scheduling
292*/
293#if 0
294#define AES_ASM
295#endif
296
297/* 5. BYTE ORDER WITHIN 32 BIT WORDS
298
299 The fundamental data processing units in Rijndael are 8-bit bytes. The
300 input, output and key input are all enumerated arrays of bytes in which
301 bytes are numbered starting at zero and increasing to one less than the
302 number of bytes in the array in question. This enumeration is only used
303 for naming bytes and does not imply any adjacency or order relationship
304 from one byte to another. When these inputs and outputs are considered
305 as bit sequences, bits 8*n to 8*n+7 of the bit sequence are mapped to
306 byte[n] with bit 8n+i in the sequence mapped to bit 7-i within the byte.
307 In this implementation bits are numbered from 0 to 7 starting at the
308 numerically least significant end of each byte (bit n represents 2^n).
309
310 However, Rijndael can be implemented more efficiently using 32-bit
311 words by packing bytes into words so that bytes 4*n to 4*n+3 are placed
312 into word[n]. While in principle these bytes can be assembled into words
313 in any positions, this implementation only supports the two formats in
314 which bytes in adjacent positions within words also have adjacent byte
315 numbers. This order is called big-endian if the lowest numbered bytes
316 in words have the highest numeric significance and little-endian if the
317 opposite applies.
318
319 This code can work in either order irrespective of the order used by the
320 machine on which it runs. Normally the internal byte order will be set
321 to the order of the processor on which the code is to be run but this
322 define can be used to reverse this in special situations
323*/
324#if 1
325#define INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER
326#elif 0
327#define INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN
328#elif 0
329#define INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER AES_BIG_ENDIAN
330#else
331#error The internal byte order is not defined
332#endif
333
334/* 6. FAST INPUT/OUTPUT OPERATIONS.
335
336 On some machines it is possible to improve speed by transferring the
337 bytes in the input and output arrays to and from the internal 32-bit
338 variables by addressing these arrays as if they are arrays of 32-bit
339 words. On some machines this will always be possible but there may
340 be a large performance penalty if the byte arrays are not aligned on
341 the normal word boundaries. On other machines this technique will
342 lead to memory access errors when such 32-bit word accesses are not
343 properly aligned. The option SAFE_IO avoids such problems but will
344 often be slower on those machines that support misaligned access
345 (especially so if care is taken to align the input and output byte
346 arrays on 32-bit word boundaries). If SAFE_IO is not defined it is
347 assumed that access to byte arrays as if they are arrays of 32-bit
348 words will not cause problems when such accesses are misaligned.
349*/
350#if 1 && !defined(_MSC_VER)
351#define SAFE_IO
352#endif
353
354/* 7. LOOP UNROLLING
355
356 The code for encryption and decrytpion cycles through a number of rounds
357 that can be implemented either in a loop or by expanding the code into a
358 long sequence of instructions, the latter producing a larger program but
359 one that will often be much faster. The latter is called loop unrolling.
360 There are also potential speed advantages in expanding two iterations in
361 a loop with half the number of iterations, which is called partial loop
362 unrolling. The following options allow partial or full loop unrolling
363 to be set independently for encryption and decryption
364*/
365#if 1
366#define ENC_UNROLL FULL
367#elif 0
368#define ENC_UNROLL PARTIAL
369#else
370#define ENC_UNROLL NONE
371#endif
372
373#if 1
374#define DEC_UNROLL FULL
375#elif 0
376#define DEC_UNROLL PARTIAL
377#else
378#define DEC_UNROLL NONE
379#endif
380
381/* 8. FAST FINITE FIELD OPERATIONS
382
383 If this section is included, tables are used to provide faster finite
384 field arithmetic (this has no effect if FIXED_TABLES is defined).
385*/
386#if 1
387#define FF_TABLES
388#endif
389
390/* 9. INTERNAL STATE VARIABLE FORMAT
391
392 The internal state of Rijndael is stored in a number of local 32-bit
393 word varaibles which can be defined either as an array or as individual
394 names variables. Include this section if you want to store these local
395 varaibles in arrays. Otherwise individual local variables will be used.
396*/
397#if 1
398#define ARRAYS
399#endif
400
401/* In this implementation the columns of the state array are each held in
402 32-bit words. The state array can be held in various ways: in an array
403 of words, in a number of individual word variables or in a number of
404 processor registers. The following define maps a variable name x and
405 a column number c to the way the state array variable is to be held.
406 The first define below maps the state into an array x[c] whereas the
407 second form maps the state into a number of individual variables x0,
408 x1, etc. Another form could map individual state colums to machine
409 register names.
410*/
411
412#if defined(ARRAYS)
413#define s(x,c) x[c]
414#else
415#define s(x,c) x##c
416#endif
417
418/* 10. VARIABLE BLOCK SIZE SPEED
419
420 This section is only relevant if you wish to use the variable block
421 length feature of the code. Include this section if you place more
422 emphasis on speed rather than code size.
423*/
424#if 1
425#define FAST_VARIABLE
426#endif
427
428/* 11. FIXED OR DYNAMIC TABLES
429
430 When this section is included the tables used by the code are comipled
431 statically into the binary file. Otherwise they are computed once when
432 the code is first used.
433*/
434#if 1
435#define FIXED_TABLES
436#endif
437
438/* 12. GLOBAL VARIABLES
439
440 In some circumstances global variables to hold the fixed tables are not
441 possible so the tables have to be placed in a structure that is passed
442 around at run time through the AES API calls. In this case FIXED_TABLES
443 cannot be used. GLOBALS must be defined in order to use the assembler
444 version of this code. If GLOBALS is not defined, then AES_TABLE_PTR must
445 be defined either on the command line or early in aes.h in order to
446 provide space for the table pointer in the AES context.
447*/
448#if 1 || defined(AES_ASM)
449#define GLOBALS
450#elif !defined(AES_TABLE_PTR)
451#error no context space for table pointer (compile with AES_TABLE_PTR defined)
452#elif defined(FIXED_TABLES)
453#undef FIXED_TABLES
454#endif
455
456/* 13. INTERNAL TABLE CONFIGURATION
457
458 This cipher proceeds by repeating in a number of cycles known as 'rounds'
459 which are implemented by a round function which can optionally be speeded
460 up using tables. The basic tables are each 256 32-bit words, with either
461 one or four tables being required for each round function depending on
462 how much speed is required. The encryption and decryption round functions
463 are different and the last encryption and decrytpion round functions are
464 different again making four different round functions in all.
465
466 This means that:
467 1. Normal encryption and decryption rounds can each use either 0, 1
468 or 4 tables and table spaces of 0, 1024 or 4096 bytes each.
469 2. The last encryption and decryption rounds can also use either 0, 1
470 or 4 tables and table spaces of 0, 1024 or 4096 bytes each.
471
472 Include or exclude the appropriate definitions below to set the number
473 of tables used by this implementation.
474*/
475
476#if 1 /* set tables for the normal encryption round */
477#define ENC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
478#elif 0
479#define ENC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
480#else
481#define ENC_ROUND NO_TABLES
482#endif
483
484#if 1 /* set tables for the last encryption round */
485#define LAST_ENC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
486#elif 0
487#define LAST_ENC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
488#else
489#define LAST_ENC_ROUND NO_TABLES
490#endif
491
492#if 1 /* set tables for the normal decryption round */
493#define DEC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
494#elif 0
495#define DEC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
496#else
497#define DEC_ROUND NO_TABLES
498#endif
499
500#if 1 /* set tables for the last decryption round */
501#define LAST_DEC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
502#elif 0
503#define LAST_DEC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
504#else
505#define LAST_DEC_ROUND NO_TABLES
506#endif
507
508/* The decryption key schedule can be speeded up with tables in the same
509 way that the round functions can. Include or exclude the following
510 defines to set this requirement.
511*/
512#if 1
513#define KEY_SCHED FOUR_TABLES
514#elif 0
515#define KEY_SCHED ONE_TABLE
516#else
517#define KEY_SCHED NO_TABLES
518#endif
519
520/* END OF CONFIGURATION OPTIONS */
521
522#if defined(BLOCK_SIZE) && ((BLOCK_SIZE & 3) || BLOCK_SIZE < 16 || BLOCK_SIZE > 32)
523#error An illegal block size has been specified.
524#endif
525
526#if !defined(BLOCK_SIZE)
527#define RC_LENGTH 29
528#else
529#define RC_LENGTH (5 * BLOCK_SIZE / 4 - (BLOCK_SIZE == 16 ? 10 : 11))
530#endif
531
532/* Disable at least some poor combinations of options */
533
534#if ENC_ROUND == NO_TABLES && LAST_ENC_ROUND != NO_TABLES
535#undef LAST_ENC_ROUND
536#define LAST_ENC_ROUND NO_TABLES
537#elif ENC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE && LAST_ENC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
538#undef LAST_ENC_ROUND
539#define LAST_ENC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
540#endif
541
542#if ENC_ROUND == NO_TABLES && ENC_UNROLL != NONE
543#undef ENC_UNROLL
544#define ENC_UNROLL NONE
545#endif
546
547#if DEC_ROUND == NO_TABLES && LAST_DEC_ROUND != NO_TABLES
548#undef LAST_DEC_ROUND
549#define LAST_DEC_ROUND NO_TABLES
550#elif DEC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE && LAST_DEC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
551#undef LAST_DEC_ROUND
552#define LAST_DEC_ROUND ONE_TABLE
553#endif
554
555#if DEC_ROUND == NO_TABLES && DEC_UNROLL != NONE
556#undef DEC_UNROLL
557#define DEC_UNROLL NONE
558#endif
559
560/* upr(x,n): rotates bytes within words by n positions, moving bytes to
561 higher index positions with wrap around into low positions
562 ups(x,n): moves bytes by n positions to higher index positions in
563 words but without wrap around
564 bval(x,n): extracts a byte from a word
565
566 NOTE: The definitions given here are intended only for use with
567 unsigned variables and with shift counts that are compile
568 time constants
569*/
570
571#if (INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER == AES_LITTLE_ENDIAN)
572#define upr(x,n) (((aes_32t)(x) << (8 * (n))) | ((aes_32t)(x) >> (32 - 8 * (n))))
573#define ups(x,n) ((aes_32t) (x) << (8 * (n)))
574#define bval(x,n) ((aes_08t)((x) >> (8 * (n))))
575#define bytes2word(b0, b1, b2, b3) \
576 (((aes_32t)(b3) << 24) | ((aes_32t)(b2) << 16) | ((aes_32t)(b1) << 8) | (b0))
577#endif
578
579#if (INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER == AES_BIG_ENDIAN)
580#define upr(x,n) (((aes_32t)(x) >> (8 * (n))) | ((aes_32t)(x) << (32 - 8 * (n))))
581#define ups(x,n) ((aes_32t) (x) >> (8 * (n))))
582#define bval(x,n) ((aes_08t)((x) >> (24 - 8 * (n))))
583#define bytes2word(b0, b1, b2, b3) \
584 (((aes_32t)(b0) << 24) | ((aes_32t)(b1) << 16) | ((aes_32t)(b2) << 8) | (b3))
585#endif
586
587#if defined(SAFE_IO)
588
589#define word_in(x) bytes2word((x)[0], (x)[1], (x)[2], (x)[3])
590#define word_out(x,v) { (x)[0] = bval(v,0); (x)[1] = bval(v,1); \
591 (x)[2] = bval(v,2); (x)[3] = bval(v,3); }
592
593#elif (INTERNAL_BYTE_ORDER == PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER)
594
595#define word_in(x) (*(aes_32t*)(x))
596#define word_out(x,v) (*(aes_32t*)(x) = (v))
597
598#else
599
600#if !defined(bswap_32)
601#define brot(x,n) (((aes_32t)(x) << n) | ((aes_32t)(x) >> (32 - n)))
602#define bswap_32(x) ((brot((x),8) & 0x00ff00ff) | (brot((x),24) & 0xff00ff00))
603#endif
604
605#define word_in(x) bswap_32(*(aes_32t*)(x))
606#define word_out(x,v) (*(aes_32t*)(x) = bswap_32(v))
607
608#endif
609
610/* the finite field modular polynomial and elements */
611
612#define WPOLY 0x011b
613#define BPOLY 0x1b
614
615/* multiply four bytes in GF(2^8) by 'x' {02} in parallel */
616
617#define m1 0x80808080
618#define m2 0x7f7f7f7f
619#define FFmulX(x) ((((x) & m2) << 1) ^ ((((x) & m1) >> 7) * BPOLY))
620
621/* The following defines provide alternative definitions of FFmulX that might
622 give improved performance if a fast 32-bit multiply is not available. Note
623 that a temporary variable u needs to be defined where FFmulX is used.
624
625#define FFmulX(x) (u = (x) & m1, u |= (u >> 1), ((x) & m2) << 1) ^ ((u >> 3) | (u >> 6))
626#define m4 (0x01010101 * BPOLY)
627#define FFmulX(x) (u = (x) & m1, ((x) & m2) << 1) ^ ((u - (u >> 7)) & m4)
628*/
629
630/* Work out which tables are needed for the different options */
631
632#ifdef AES_ASM
633#ifdef ENC_ROUND
634#undef ENC_ROUND
635#endif
636#define ENC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
637#ifdef LAST_ENC_ROUND
638#undef LAST_ENC_ROUND
639#endif
640#define LAST_ENC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
641#ifdef DEC_ROUND
642#undef DEC_ROUND
643#endif
644#define DEC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
645#ifdef LAST_DEC_ROUND
646#undef LAST_DEC_ROUND
647#endif
648#define LAST_DEC_ROUND FOUR_TABLES
649#ifdef KEY_SCHED
650#undef KEY_SCHED
651#define KEY_SCHED FOUR_TABLES
652#endif
653#endif
654
655#if defined(ENCRYPTION) || defined(AES_ASM)
656#if ENC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE
657#define FT1_SET
658#elif ENC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
659#define FT4_SET
660#else
661#define SBX_SET
662#endif
663#if LAST_ENC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE
664#define FL1_SET
665#elif LAST_ENC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
666#define FL4_SET
667#elif !defined(SBX_SET)
668#define SBX_SET
669#endif
670#endif
671
672#if defined(DECRYPTION) || defined(AES_ASM)
673#if DEC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE
674#define IT1_SET
675#elif DEC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
676#define IT4_SET
677#else
678#define ISB_SET
679#endif
680#if LAST_DEC_ROUND == ONE_TABLE
681#define IL1_SET
682#elif LAST_DEC_ROUND == FOUR_TABLES
683#define IL4_SET
684#elif !defined(ISB_SET)
685#define ISB_SET
686#endif
687#endif
688
689#if defined(ENCRYPTION_KEY_SCHEDULE) || defined(DECRYPTION_KEY_SCHEDULE)
690#if KEY_SCHED == ONE_TABLE
691#define LS1_SET
692#define IM1_SET
693#elif KEY_SCHED == FOUR_TABLES
694#define LS4_SET
695#define IM4_SET
696#elif !defined(SBX_SET)
697#define SBX_SET
698#endif
699#endif
700
701/* If there are no global variables, the AES tables are placed in
702 a structure and a pointer is added to the AES context. If this
703 facility is used, the calling program has to ensure that this
704 pointer is managed appropriately. In particular, the value of
705 the t_dec(in,it) item in the table structure must be set to zero
706 in order to ensure that the tables are initialised. In practice
707 the three code sequences in aeskey.c that control the calls to
708 gen_tabs() and the gen_tabs() routine itself will require some
709 changes for a specific implementation. If global variables are
710 available it will generally be preferable to use them with the
711 precomputed FIXED_TABLES option that uses static global tables.
712
713 The following defines can be used to control the way the tables
714 are defined, initialised and used in embedded environments that
715 require special features for these purposes
716
717 the 't_dec' construction is used to declare fixed table arrays
718 the 't_set' construction is used to set fixed table values
719 the 't_use' construction is used to access fixed table values
720
721 256 byte tables:
722
723 t_xxx(s,box) => forward S box
724 t_xxx(i,box) => inverse S box
725
726 256 32-bit word OR 4 x 256 32-bit word tables:
727
728 t_xxx(f,n) => forward normal round
729 t_xxx(f,l) => forward last round
730 t_xxx(i,n) => inverse normal round
731 t_xxx(i,l) => inverse last round
732 t_xxx(l,s) => key schedule table
733 t_xxx(i,m) => key schedule table
734
735 Other variables and tables:
736
737 t_xxx(in,it) => the table initialsation flag
738 t_xxx(r,c) => the rcon table
739*/
740
741#define t_dec(m,n) t_##m##n
742#define t_set(m,n) t_##m##n /* may be redefined once below */
743#define t_use(m,n) t_##m##n /* may be redefined once below */
744
745#ifdef FIXED_TABLES
746
747#define prefx extern const
748#elif defined(GLOBALS)
749#define prefx extern
750extern aes_08t t_dec(in,it);
751void gen_tabs(void);
752#else
753#define prefx
754void gen_tabs(aes_ctx cx[1]);
755
756typedef struct {
757#endif
758
759prefx aes_32t t_dec(r,c)[RC_LENGTH];
760
761#ifdef SBX_SET
762prefx aes_08t t_dec(s,box)[256];
763#endif
764
765#ifdef ISB_SET
766prefx aes_08t t_dec(i,box)[256];
767#endif
768
769#ifdef FT1_SET
770prefx aes_32t t_dec(f,n)[256];
771#endif
772
773#ifdef FT4_SET
774prefx aes_32t t_dec(f,n)[4][256];
775#endif
776
777#ifdef FL1_SET
778prefx aes_32t t_dec(f,l)[256];
779#endif
780
781#ifdef FL4_SET
782prefx aes_32t t_dec(f,l)[4][256];
783#endif
784
785#ifdef IT1_SET
786prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,n)[256];
787#endif
788
789#ifdef IT4_SET
790prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,n)[4][256];
791#endif
792
793#ifdef IL1_SET
794prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,l)[256];
795#endif
796
797#ifdef IL4_SET
798prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,l)[4][256];
799#endif
800
801#ifdef LS1_SET
802#ifdef FL1_SET
803#undef LS1_SET
804#else
805prefx aes_32t t_dec(l,s)[256];
806#endif
807#endif
808
809#ifdef LS4_SET
810#ifdef FL4_SET
811#undef LS4_SET
812#else
813prefx aes_32t t_dec(l,s)[4][256];
814#endif
815#endif
816
817#ifdef IM1_SET
818prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,m)[256];
819#endif
820
821#ifdef IM4_SET
822prefx aes_32t t_dec(i,m)[4][256];
823#endif
824
825prefx aes_08t t_dec(in,it);
826
827#ifndef GLOBALS
828} s_ty;
829
830extern s_ty s_t;
831
832/* modify the table set macro to cope with a static structure */
833#undef t_set
834#define t_set(m,n) (s_t.t_##m##n)
835
836/* modify the table use macro to cope with a context pointer */
837#undef t_use
838#define t_use(m,n) (((s_ty*)cx->t_ptr)->t_##m##n)
839
840#endif
841
842/* Set the number of columns in nc. Note that it is important
843 that nc is a constant which is known at compile time if the
844 highest speed version of the code is needed.
845*/
846
847#if defined(BLOCK_SIZE)
848#define nc (BLOCK_SIZE >> 2)
849#else
850#define nc (cx->n_blk >> 2)
851#endif
852
853/* generic definitions of Rijndael macros that use tables */
854
855#define no_table(x,box,vf,rf,c) bytes2word( \
856 box[bval(vf(x,0,c),rf(0,c))], \
857 box[bval(vf(x,1,c),rf(1,c))], \
858 box[bval(vf(x,2,c),rf(2,c))], \
859 box[bval(vf(x,3,c),rf(3,c))])
860
861#define one_table(x,op,tab,vf,rf,c) \
862 ( tab[bval(vf(x,0,c),rf(0,c))] \
863 ^ op(tab[bval(vf(x,1,c),rf(1,c))],1) \
864 ^ op(tab[bval(vf(x,2,c),rf(2,c))],2) \
865 ^ op(tab[bval(vf(x,3,c),rf(3,c))],3))
866
867#define four_tables(x,tab,vf,rf,c) \
868 ( tab[0][bval(vf(x,0,c),rf(0,c))] \
869 ^ tab[1][bval(vf(x,1,c),rf(1,c))] \
870 ^ tab[2][bval(vf(x,2,c),rf(2,c))] \
871 ^ tab[3][bval(vf(x,3,c),rf(3,c))])
872
873#define vf1(x,r,c) (x)
874#define rf1(r,c) (r)
875#define rf2(r,c) ((8+r-c)&3)
876
877/* perform forward and inverse column mix operation on four bytes in long word x in */
878/* parallel. NOTE: x must be a simple variable, NOT an expression in these macros. */
879
880#define dec_fmvars
881#if defined(FM4_SET) /* not currently used */
882#define fwd_mcol(x) four_tables(x,t_use(f,m),vf1,rf1,0)
883#elif defined(FM1_SET) /* not currently used */
884#define fwd_mcol(x) one_table(x,upr,t_use(f,m),vf1,rf1,0)
885#else
886#undef dec_fmvars
887#define dec_fmvars aes_32t f1, f2;
888#define fwd_mcol(x) (f1 = (x), f2 = FFmulX(f1), f2 ^ upr(f1 ^ f2, 3) ^ upr(f1, 2) ^ upr(f1, 1))
889#endif
890
891#define dec_imvars
892#if defined(IM4_SET)
893#define inv_mcol(x) four_tables(x,t_use(i,m),vf1,rf1,0)
894#elif defined(IM1_SET)
895#define inv_mcol(x) one_table(x,upr,t_use(i,m),vf1,rf1,0)
896#else
897#undef dec_imvars
898#define dec_imvars aes_32t f2, f4, f8, f9;
899#define inv_mcol(x) \
900 (f9 = (x), f2 = FFmulX(f9), f4 = FFmulX(f2), f8 = FFmulX(f4), f9 ^= f8, \
901 f2 ^= f4 ^ f8 ^ upr(f2 ^ f9,3) ^ upr(f4 ^ f9,2) ^ upr(f9,1))
902#endif
903
904#if defined(FL4_SET)
905#define ls_box(x,c) four_tables(x,t_use(f,l),vf1,rf2,c)
906#elif defined(LS4_SET)
907#define ls_box(x,c) four_tables(x,t_use(l,s),vf1,rf2,c)
908#elif defined(FL1_SET)
909#define ls_box(x,c) one_table(x,upr,t_use(f,l),vf1,rf2,c)
910#elif defined(LS1_SET)
911#define ls_box(x,c) one_table(x,upr,t_use(l,s),vf1,rf2,c)
912#else
913#define ls_box(x,c) no_table(x,t_use(s,box),vf1,rf2,c)
914#endif
915
916#if defined(__cplusplus)
917}
918#endif
919
920#endif
921
